Lluís Companys 23, Barcelona08010, Catalonia, Spain * Corresponding author Heteroatom doping serves as an important strategy to improve the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity of transition-metal compounds, while the investigation of intrinsic active sites and mechanisms remains insufficient. In this work, a facile cation regulation strategy is reported to boost the OER activity of metal sulfides via pyrolysis of the Ni-Co bimetallic metal-organic framework. The obtained Ni-substituted CoS nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon (Ni-CoS/NC) catalyst achieves a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a small overpotential of 270 mV with a Tafel slope of 37 mV dec−1 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH. Through a combination of spectroscopy study and theoretical computations, the activity origin is revealed at the atomic level. The Co x Ni1–x OOH serves as the real active site for the OER generated by the Ni-CoS/NC reconstruction under oxidation potential during OER. The Ni substitution results in a strong electronic interaction between the two metals, thus generating more negatively charged Co atoms and more positively charged Ni atoms in the electrocatalyst. The metal sites with regulated electronic structure exhibit enhanced surface adsorption of OOH* and reduce the OER overpotential. Meanwhile, the conductive porous carbon scaffold facilitates electron transfer, mass diffusion, and the accessibility of active sites. This work not only provides a feasible cation regulation strategy for the design of high-performance electrocatalysts for low-cost energy storage and conversion systems, but also yields fresh insight into the activity enhancement mechanisms and intrinsic active sites. Graphical Abstract Substitution of Co sites in CoOOH by Ni results in more negatively charged Co sites and more positively charged Ni sites, thus promoting the surface adsorption of OOH* and reducing the OER overpotential. Keywords Metal-organic framework Cation regulation Metal sulfide Metal oxyhydroxide Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is critical for electrochemical energy storage and conversion technologies, including water splitting and metal-air batteries [1–3]. The OER process involves a consecutive four-electron transfer, thus resulting in sluggish kinetics. Usually, a high overpotential is required to drive the reaction, which severely limits energy conversion efficiency and practical catalyst stability. Precious metal-based materials (like IrO2 and RuO2 as the benchmark for OER) are scarce and expensive, which is a barrier to their large-scale application [4–6]. Hence it is highly desirable but challenging to design efficient and durable OER electrocatalysts using low-cost and earth-abundant elements. In the past decades, much effort has been devoted to exploring new low-cost, high-activity, and durable electrocatalysts for OER [7–9]. Among them, iron/cobalt/nickel-based oxides, hydroxides, chalcogenides, and phosphides are considered as promising candidates due to their relatively superior activity and stability [10–13]. However, the state-of-the-art electrocatalytic performance of these electrocatalysts still does not meet the required electrocatalytic performance needed for practical applications due to: (1) limited intrinsic activity, (2) a low density of active sites, and (3) poor electrical conductivity. Therefore, it is plausible to develop effective strategies to boost the OER performance by addressing the above-mentioned issues. It has been reported that the electrocatalytic activity of OER depends on the Gibbs free adsorption energies of OER intermediates (HO*, O*, and HOO*) on the surface of active sites, among which the formation of HOO* is typically the rate-determining step (RDS) [14–16]. To achieve higher electrocatalytic performance, multi-metal components have been introduced into the electrocatalyst to modulate the OER electrocatalytic activity [17,18]. The theoretical calculation and in-depth characterization of the multi-metal materials demonstrated that the strong electronic interaction between different metal species can contribute to enhanced electrocatalytic activity compared to single-metal counterparts [19–21]. Durrant and co-workers [22] investigated the doping effects of Mn, Co, Fe, and Zn in nickel oxides on the intrinsic activity of OER. It is found that the oxygen binding energetics are decreased from Mn- < Co- < Fe-< Zn-doped samples, which significantly affects the OER kinetics. However, most of the previous works focus on the doping effect on the main component, while the electrocatalytic activity changes of the doped metals are usually ignored. It should be noted that the doped metals are also an active component of the OER [23], which may yield a significant effect on the OER performance. In addition to metal compositions, the nanostructure of electrocatalysts also influences the electrochemical performance [24]. Hybridizing transition metal components with porous carbon is an effective approach to enhance the OER activity owing to abundant active sites and improved electrical conductivity [25–28]. To this end, it is highly desirable and challenging to develop hybrid electrocatalysts with multi-metal components to boost the OER performance and clarify the effect of each metal component on the enhancement of the OER activity. In line with the above understanding, an effective cation regulation strategy is proposed to tailor the electronic structure of multi-metal components for enhanced OER activity. The partial substitution of cobalt sites by nickel in CoS nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon (Ni-CoS/NC) is achieved by pyrolysis of bimetallic CoNi-based metal-organic framework (CoNi-MOF). MOFs with tunable metal sites and structures are interesting self-sacrificial templates for the synthesis of hybrid electrocatalysts. Electrochemical results confirm that the Ni-CoS/NC displays an improved OER electrocatalytic activity than the CoS/NC and NiS/NC in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH. The superior electrocatalytic activity is attributed to the high density of metal sites exposed on the surface and the regulated electronic structure due to the partial cation substitution. Spectroscopy characterization and theoretical calculations reveal that the Ni-substituted CoS undergoes a reconstruction to form amorphous Co x Ni1–x OOH during the OER, which serves as the real active site of the OER. The Ni substitution rendered more negatively charged Co atoms and more positively charged Ni atoms, thereby improving the adsorption of OOH* on the metal sites and decreasing the overpotential for OER. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The bimetallic M(HBTC)(4,4′-bipy)·3DMF (M = Co and Ni) MOF was synthesized based on previous work [29]. For the CoNi-MOF, 2.910 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.582 g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.844 g trimesic acid (H3BTC), and 0.768 g 4,4-bipyridyl were dissolved in 80 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF); then, the above solution was heated to 50 °C and kept for 72 h; finally, the obtained product was washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried at 60 °C overnight. The Co-MOF and Ni-MOF were prepared by the use of only one metal salt. The Ni-CoS/NC was synthesized through a high-temperature pyrolysis process. Typically, 0.72 g CoNi-MOF was ground with 1.92 g sulfur powder. Then, the mixture was pyrolyzed at 700 °C for 2 h in argon to obtain the Ni-CoS/NC. The CoS/NC and NiS/NC were obtained by the same procedure but using Co-MOF or Ni-MOF precursors. 2.2 Physicochemical characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Bruker AXS D8 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.15405 nm) with 2θ ranging from 5° to 80° (step size: 0.02°) at 40 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected with a PHI quantum-2000. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova NanoSEM 450) was employed to observe the morphologies and microstructures. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) were performed on an FEI Tecnai F20 field emission gun microscope (200 kV with a point-to-point resolution of 0.19 nm). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Varian 720-ES) was used to determine the metal content. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K (Micromeritics ASAP 2020, US) were used to investigate the pore structure of the samples. Before measuring, the samples were degassed at 100 °C for 12 h. The specific surface area was determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model, while the pore size distribution was analyzed using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements A BioLogic SP-200 Potentiostatic Electrochemical Workstation was used to characterize the electrochemical properties at room temperature (25 °C). 100 μL catalyst ink coated on carbon paper (1.0 cm × 0.5 cm, Toray 90) and dried at room temperature was used as the working electrode (catalyst loading: 1.0 mg cm−2). The catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 5.0 mg catalyst in the mixed solution of 460 μL ethanol and 40 μL 5 wt% Nafion (Nafion® DE 520, Sigma-Aldrich) and sonicated for 30 min. To evaluate the electrocatalytic OER activity, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted in O2-saturated 1.0 mol L−1 KOH from 0.91 and 1.78 V vs. RHE at 10 mV s−1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an amplitude of 5 mV (peak-to-peak) at an applied potential of 1.53 V vs. RHE. The electrical double-layer capacitance (C dl) was used to determine the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA). The CV was tested in the non-Faradaic range of 0.805 to 0.905 V vs. RHE at scan rates from 80 to 260 mV s−1. The C dl was extracted from the slope of the plot of half current densities versus scan rates at the electrode potential of 0.855 V vs. RHE. 2.4 Computational details The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed in the CP2K Quickstep code [30]. The Gaussian-type basis set was used to represent the Kohn-Sham orbitals and the plane-wave basis set was used to reexpand electron density in reciprocal space. The nonlocal exchange and correlation energies were described using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [31]. To correct the dispersion energy, the Grimme D3 correction has been applied in all calculations [32]. 3 Results and discussion The Ni-CoS/NC sample is synthesized by a facile pyrolysis process. First, the CoNi-MOF was prepared by a solvothermal reaction between metal salts and organic linkers in DMF at 50 °C. SEM images and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mappings show that the CoNi-MOF exhibits a morphology of hexagon platelets with an uniform distribution of Co and Ni (Fig. S1). The CoNi-MOF exhibits the same XRD pattern as the mono-metal Co-MOF and its simulated pattern (Fig. S2). During the pyrolysis of CoNi-MOF and sulfur powders at 700 °C under argon, the sulfur atoms diffuse to and react with metal sites to form metal sulfides. Meanwhile, the ligands in MOF are converted into nitrogen-doped carbon, which serves as a scaffold to disperse and anchor the metal sulfides. The control samples (NiS/NC and CoS/NC) are also prepared by the same procedure except for the use of only one metal salt (Figs. S3 and S4). The nanostructure of the as-obtained Ni-CoS/NC is characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Figs. 1(a) and (b) , the Ni-CoS/NC sample consists of closely stacked irregular nanoparticles on a carbon scaffold. Meanwhile, there are some sheet-like nanostructures around these nanoparticles (Fig. 1(c)). The carbon layer prevents the aggregation of the sulfide nanoparticles at a high temperature and provides a conductive framework to connect these electrocatalytic active sites. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image in Fig. 1(d) shows that the nanoparticles exhibit a size below 20 nm. Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) maps identify the existence of Co, Ni, S, N, O, and C in this sample (Fig. 1(d), and Fig. S5). The distribution of Co, Ni, and S nearly overlap with each other, suggesting uniform sulfurization and Ni-substitution. XRD is employed to reveal the crystal structure of the metal sulfides. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 30.5°, 35.1°, 46.9°, and 54.2° correspond to the (100), (101), (102), and (110) planes of CoS, respectively (Fig. S4(b)). The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 29.9°, 33.5°, 34.4°, 45.5°, 53.2°, and 72.6° are assigned to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), and (202) planes of NiS, respectively (Fig. S4(c)). As compared in Fig. 1(e), the Ni-CoS/NC displays nearly the same diffraction peaks as CoS/NC with a tiny shift to lower angles. This reveals the distortion of the CoS lattice due to the partial substitution of Co cations by larger Ni cations [33–35]. The cobalt and/or nickel content of all samples lies between 36 wt% and 44 wt% as measured by ICP-OES (Fig. S6). The molar ratio of Co to Ni in Ni-CoS/NC is 3.06 to 1. N2 adsorption/desorption results reveal that both CoS/NC and Ni-CoS/NC exhibit type-IV isotherms, indicating their mesoporous structure (Fig. S7(a)) [36,37]. After Ni substitution, the specific surface area decreases from 121 m2 g−1 of CoS/NC to 107 m2 g−1 of Ni-CoS/NC, which is probably due to the increase in metal content. The Ni-CoS/NC displays a broader pore size distribution compared to CoS/NC with larger mesopores (Fig. S7(b)). The surface elemental composition and valence states of Ni-CoS/NC are investigated by XPS. The XPS survey spectrum shows that C, N, O, S, Co, and Ni are present in Ni-CoS/NC (Fig. S8 and Table S1). The oxygen probably originates from the surface oxidation of the metal sulfide and nitrogen-oxide species of the nitrogen-doped carbon [38]. The Co 2p 3/2 for Ni-CoS/NC shows a negative shift to lower binding energy than CoS/NC, while Ni 2p 3/2 for Ni-CoS/NC shows a positive shift to higher binding energy than NiS/NC (Fig. 2 (a)). Moreover, the binding energy of S 2p peaks is constant after Ni substitution (Fig. 2(b)), which is in contrast to a previous report [39]. These results reveal that there is a strong electronic interaction between Co and Ni, which highlights the crucial role of cation sites in varied electrocatalytic activity. Further deconvolution and interpretation of the Co 2p and Ni 2p XPS spectra provide more quantitative information on the change in valence states (Figs. 2(c)–(e) and Fig. S9). For the Co 2p 3/2 spectrum, the peaks at 778.5, 781.3, and 784.4 eV are assigned to Co3+, Co2+, and satellite peaks (referred to as “Sat.” in the figure) [40]. The peaks at 853.0, 855.7, and 861.4 eV were attributed to Ni2+, Ni3+, and satellite peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 [41]. As summarized in Fig. 2(c), the proportion of the high-valence species for Ni-CoS/NC increased from 38% to 56% after Ni substitution. The change of valence states is attributed to the altered local electron distribution derived from moderate Ni substitution, which will benefit the adsorption of reaction intermediates and ultimately lead to higher OER activity [42–44]. For the S 2p spectrum, the peaks at 163.9, 165.1, and 168.7 eV were attributed to S 2p 3/2, S 2p 3/1, and SO4 2– (Fig. 2(f) and Fig. S12) [45,46]. The peak at 161.9 eV was assigned to S-H [47]. The electrocatalytic OER activities of the catalysts are evaluated in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH. The Ni/Co metal ratios and pyrolysis temperatures are first. It is seen that the electrocatalyst with a Ni/Co metal ratio of 1:3 and pyrolyzed at 700 °C exhibits the best OER performance (Figs. S11 and S12). As expected, Ni-CoS/NC exhibits the highest OER electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 3 (a)). The Ni-CoS/NC material reaches a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential (η) of 270 mV, which is smaller than that of CoS/NC (308 mV) and NiS/NC (322 mV) (Fig. 3(b)). A large current density of 50 and 100 mA cm−2 can be achieved at η of 320 and 350 mV, respectively, rendering the Ni-CoS/NC material one of the best transition metal-based OER electrocatalysts (Table S2), which also highlights the crucial role of cation sites on varied electrocatalytic activity. The Tafel slopes of the catalysts are calculated to study the OER kinetics (Fig. 3(c)). Ni-CoS/NC has a Tafel slope of 37 mV dec−1, which is much smaller than that of CoS/NC (48 mV dec−1) and NiS/NC (72 mV dec−1). Furthermore, EIS and the ECSA are measured. As shown in Fig. 3(d), Ni-CoS/NC exhibits a smaller charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 4.7 Ω than that of CoS/NC (9.2 Ω) and NiS/NC (22.1 Ω). This further confirms that Ni substitution enhances the charge transfer property of the Ni-CoS/NC catalyst, which may be attributed to the increased intrinsic activity. The electrical double-layer capacitance (C dl) is usually used to evaluate the ECSA of the materials, which can be extracted from the slope of current densities versus scan rates (Fig. 3(e); Fig. S13). The C dl of Ni-CoS/NC is near twice that of CoS/NC and NiS/NC, implying that more exposed active sites can be facilely accessed by the electrolyte. To exclude the effect of metal content and ECSA on the OER performance, the OER currents are further normalized to the mass of metals and C dl. It is seen that the OER performances show the same trends as the results in Fig. 3(a), which indicates that the metal content does not affect the electrocatalytic activity (Fig. S14). Finally, the stability of the Ni-CoS/NC catalysts is tested with chronopotentiometric, and potential cycling methods (Fig. 3(f), and Fig. S15). The Ni-CoS/NC catalyst shows excellent stability without any obvious degradation after 300 h at 50 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3(f)). It has been reported in previous work that the transition metal chalcogenides are not thermodynamically stable and can be partially or fully oxidized to the corresponding metal hydroxides or oxyhydroxides under oxidation potential in alkaline media [48–51]. To reveal the real active site of the OER, the Ni-CoS/NC catalyst is characterized after a stability test (Fig. 4 ). It is found that the diffraction peaks of Ni-CoS/NC disappeared from the XRD pattern and without any new diffraction peaks detected, suggesting the reconstruction of the catalyst during OER (Fig. 4(a)). There is no obvious S 2p XPS spectrum was detected after the OER, indicating the loss of sulfur from Ni-CoS/NC (Fig. 4(b)). It is seen that the binding energy of Co 2p 3/2 peak is located at 779.9 eV after the stability test, which correspond to the cobalt oxide/oxyhydroxide (Fig. 4(c)) [52–54]. The EELS maps further confirm the above-mentioned results. It is seen that there is a matrix composed of C and O that surrounds smaller nanostructures containing Ni and Co (Fig. 4(d)), indicating the possible formation of metal oxide/oxyhydroxides. And no signal of S was detected further confirming the loss of S after the stability test. The nanocrystal structure is further characterized by the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and its corresponding Fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns. The magnified detail of the orange squared region in Fig. 4(e) and its corresponding FFT patterns are shown in Figs. 4(f) and (g). It is seen that the same selected region is in agreement with different possible crystal structures, including CoO(OH) (P63/mmc), NiO(OH) (P3m1), NiO(OH) (C1m1), and NiO(OH) (C12m1). Taking into account the EELS maps, FFT patterns, XPS spectra, and XRD patterns, the most probable structure would be amorphous Co x Ni1–x OOH. The amorphous Co x Ni1–x OOH electrocatalyst may exhibit abundant active sites and increased intrinsic activity due to its disordered structure [55,56]. To better understand the origin of the improved electrocatalytic performances after Ni substitution, DFT calculations are performed based on the four-electron pathway mechanism (Details in Supplemental material). The (100) surface of CoOOH, Ni-CoOOH, and NiOOH are allowed to adsorb the OER intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*) due to the lowest specific surface energy among all considered surfaces. All Ni–Co arrangements in a 2 × 2 × 1 supercell are considered in the Ni-substituted CoOOH models (Ni:Co = 1:3). The adsorption Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) of each OER step at given potentials are shown in Fig. 5 . The step with the largest ΔG value is considered as the RDS. The adsorption of OOH* species, which prefers the bridge site of two Co atoms, is revealed to be the RDS step for the CoOOH, Co x Ni1–x OOH, and NiOOH models (Fig. 5 and Figs. S16-S18). For the formation of OOH* at the OER equilibrium potential (1.23 V vs. RHE), the energy barriers on Co site is 1.44 eV for CoOOH and 1.22 eV for Co x Ni1–x OOH (Fig. 5(a)), while the energy barriers on Ni site is 1.50 eV for NiOOH and 0.74 eV for Co x Ni1–x OOH (Fig. 5(b)). The reduced energy barrier on Ni-substituted CoOOH is ascribed to the enhanced interaction between OOH* and metal atoms. The Co atoms can withdraw electrons from the adjacent Ni atoms, which results in more negatively charged Co atoms and more positively charged Ni atoms (Fig. S19). These results confirm that Ni substitution can alter the electronic structure of the adjacent Co sites and itself, thus promoting the adsorption of OOH*, and reducing the OER overpotential, which is consistent with the experimental results. 4 Conclusions In summary, a MOF-derived cation regulation strategy was demonstrated to enhance the OER activity of metal sulfides. The pyrolysis of bimetallic MOF precursors generated Ni-substituted CoS nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon scaffolds. The Ni-CoS/NC displayed a high activity for OER with an overpotential of 270, 320, and 350 mV at 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2, respectively, as well as outstanding stability for 300 hours. Post-OER characterizations of the electrocatalysts confirmed that the active sites are amorphous Co x Ni1-x OOH., which are generated from Ni-substituted CoS by electrochemical oxidation during the OER. The Co atoms can withdraw electrons from the adjacent Ni atoms thus optimizing intermediate adsorption-free energy on the metal sites to promote the OER activity. This work provides a new cation substitution strategy and improved mechanistic understanding of cation substitution of transition-metal compounds, which could lead to highly active and cost-effective electrocatalysts for a wide range of energy storage and conversion applications. coredata.dc:description: Heteroatom doping serves as an important strategy to improve the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity of transition-metal compounds, while the investigation of intrinsic active sites and mechanisms remains insufficient. In this work, a facile cation regulation strategy is reported to boost the OER activity of metal sulfides via pyrolysis of the Ni-Co bimetallic metal-organic framework. The obtained Ni-substituted CoS nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon (Ni-CoS/NC) catalyst achieves a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a small overpotential of 270 mV with a Tafel slope of 37 mV dec−1 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH. Through a combination of spectroscopy study and theoretical computations, the activity origin is revealed at the atomic level. The Co x Ni1–x OOH serves as the real active site for the OER generated by the Ni-CoS/NC reconstruction under oxidation potential during OER. The Ni substitution results in a strong electronic interaction between the two metals, thus generating more negatively charged Co atoms and more positively charged Ni atoms in the electrocatalyst. The metal sites with regulated electronic structure exhibit enhanced surface adsorption of OOH* and reduce the OER overpotential. Meanwhile, the conductive porous carbon scaffold facilitates electron transfer, mass diffusion, and the accessibility of active sites. This work not only provides a feasible cation regulation strategy for the design of high-performance electrocatalysts for low-cost energy storage and conversion systems, but also yields fresh insight into the activity enhancement mechanisms and intrinsic active sites.
